title: Investigate 12-factor-agents patterns for skill/agent improvements
description:
## Overview
Research the 12-factor-agents framework from HumanLayer to identify patterns and principles that could improve hyperpowers skills and agents.

## Source
https://github.com/humanlayer/12-factor-agents

## Goals
- [ ] Understand the 12 factors/principles for building agents
- [ ] Identify which factors already apply to our skills/agents
- [ ] Find gaps where adopting these patterns could improve reliability, composability, or observability
- [ ] Document actionable recommendations for hyperpowers

## Context
This is a research task to evaluate external best practices and determine applicability to our agent architecture.

title: Make research skill more extensive with deeper parallel agents
description:
## Problem

## Proposed Improvements
1. **More parallel agents** - Dispatch additional specialized agents to cover more research angles simultaneously
2. **Deeper research per agent** - Each agent should explore more thoroughly rather than surface-level investigation

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Increase the number of parallel research agents dispatched
- [ ] Configure agents to do deeper exploration (more file reads, more grep searches, follow references further)
- [ ] Maintain reasonable context/token usage despite increased depth

title: Incorporate the Ralph Wiggum technique into Hyperpowers
description:
Investigate and incorporate the Ralph Wiggum technique - an agentic coding pattern that uses a simple loop to continuously run AI agents for autonomous code generation.

## Background

The Ralph Wiggum Technique was created by Geoff Huntley. The core implementation is:

```bash
while :; do cat PROMPT.md | npx --yes @sourcegraph/amp ; done
```

## Key Concepts

- **Context Engineering**: Carving work into independent context windows rather than running indefinitely to avoid "overbaking"
- **Declarative Specifications**: Using detailed prompt files that describe desired outcomes
- **Iterative Refinement**: AI agent repeatedly processes prompts, refining across iterations

## Resources

- Blog post: https://www.humanlayer.dev/blog/brief-history-of-ralph
- GitHub repo: https://github.com/ai-that-works/ai-that-works/tree/main/2025-10-28-ralph-wiggum-coding-agent-power-tools
- Saved HTML: docs/references/ralph-wiggum-technique.html

## Potential Applications for Hyperpowers

- Code refactoring with standardized guidelines
- Specification generation from requirements
- New project scaffolding
- Incremental improvements to existing codebases

title: Reinforce spec/issue context preservation throughout brainstorm→research→plan→develop cycle
description:
## Problem

Details from original specs (issues, tickets, requirements) can get lost as work progresses through the skill cycle:
- brainstorm → research → plan → develop

Each transition risks dropping important context from the originating issue/spec.

## Solution

Add reinforcement mechanisms to ensure original spec details are:
1. Captured at the start of the cycle
2. Carried forward through each skill transition
3. Referenced in final deliverables

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Identify where context is currently lost in skill transitions
- [ ] Add explicit spec/issue context forwarding in relevant skills
- [ ] Create tests verifying context preservation through full cycle
- [ ] Test with real issue → brainstorm → research → plan → develop flow

title: Clarify skill pipeline flow: brainstorm → research → planning → development
description:

1. **Brainstorm** → suggests research at the end
2. **Research** → suggests planning at the end, creates a master research document

Key changes for research skill:
- Create a larger master document that incorporates the brainstorm work that came before
- The master document should avoid duplication
- Minimize ambiguity - all questions and research should be explored
- Output should be ready for a development plan to be made from it

This creates a clear document flow through the skill pipeline.

title: Bubble up code quality/spec issue details in subagent-driven development
description:
## Problem

When subagent-driven development finds and fixes code quality or spec issues, the main session user only sees minimal feedback like:

> The code quality reviewer found issues. Let me read the file and apply fixes.

No details about what the actual issues were or what was fixed are bubbled up to the human operator.

## Expected Behavior

When issues are found and fixed, bubble up a brief summary including:
- A small code snippet showing the problematic code
- What the issue was (e.g., "Missing accessibility label", "Potential nil crash")
- What fix was applied

## Example

Instead of just:
> The code quality reviewer found issues. Let me read the file and apply fixes.

Show something like:
> **Code quality issues found and fixed:**
> - `Button(action: ...) { Image(...) }` → Added accessibility label
> - Brief explanation of the fix

This gives the human operator visibility into what automated fixes are being applied without requiring them to dig through code diffs.

title: Make issue tracking steps non-negotiable in subagent-driven-development skill
description:
## Problem

The subagent-driven-development skill is skipping the step to set beads issues to 'in_progress' when starting development work. This defeats the purpose of issue tracking integration.

## Required Fix

Make ALL issue-related OFFERS in the skill NON-NEGOTIABLE and COMPULSORY:

1. **At start of development**: MUST offer to update issue status to `in_progress` - cannot skip asking
2. **At completion**: 
   - MUST offer to close/update the original issue
   - If any work was discovered during implementation, MUST offer to create issues for them

The **offers themselves are mandatory** - the skill cannot skip presenting these options. However, the **user has final say** on whether to accept each offer.

**Important**: Do NOT interrupt implementation to offer issue creation. Discovered work is tracked internally and offered only at the end.
close_reason: Implemented mandatory issue tracking offers across three skills: subagent-driven-development (session start), verification-before-completion (pre-completion), and finishing-a-development-branch (post-merge). Documented in CLAUDE.md.

title: Add context: fork option to systematic-debugging skill
description:
## Summary

Add support for `context: fork` to the systematic-debugging skill, allowing its heavy 4-phase investigation process to run in an isolated sub-agent context.

## Background

The systematic-debugging skill is one of the most investigation-heavy skills in the library:

- **4 rigorous phases:** Root Cause Investigation → Pattern Analysis → Hypothesis Testing → Implementation
- **11 supporting files:** root-cause tracing, defense-in-depth, condition-based waiting, test scenarios, etc.
- **Extensive exploration:** reading errors, git diffs, stack traces, running diagnostics, comparing code patterns
- **Scientific method enforcement:** hypothesis forming, minimal testing, verification loops

## Why Fork Would Benefit This Skill

**Token efficiency:**
- Investigation involves many file reads, grep searches, git operations
- Evidence gathering (logging component boundaries, tracing data flow) produces verbose output
- Failed hypotheses and their tests consume tokens but aren't needed afterward

**Context cleanliness:**
- The investigation *journey* (hypotheses tried, evidence gathered, dead ends) pollutes main context
- The investigation *result* (root cause identified, fix verified) is what matters for subsequent work
- Main session stays focused on implementation rather than debugging archaeology

**Clean handoff:**
- When debugging completes, return to main context with:
  - Root cause summary
  - The fix applied
  - Test verification
- Not the full trail of hypothesis → test → fail → new hypothesis loops

## Proposed Change

Add `context: fork` to the skill frontmatter:

\`\`\`yaml
---
name: systematic-debugging
description: Use when encountering any bug, test failure, or unexpected behavior
context: fork
---
\`\`\`

## Considerations

- Users may sometimes want to see the full investigation trail in main context
- Could be made configurable (fork by default, with option to run inline)
- Related skill `superpowers:test-driven-development` referenced in Phase 4 would need coordination if both fork

## Related

- GitHub issue: https://github.com/obra/superpowers/issues/246
- Related to brainstorming fork feature (superpowers #245)
- Claude Code CLI 2.1.2 fork feature

title: Reinforce all skills with verification checkpoints
description:
## Problem

Claude is following skills less consistently. All skills need reinforcement and verification checkpoints to ensure Claude follows each step.

## Observed Issues

- **subagent-driven-development**: Tests written but not run
- **Handoff files**: Written but not used/consumed by receiving agents

## Solution

Audit all skills and add reinforcement mechanisms where missing:

1. **Verification gates** - Add checkpoints that block progression until previous step verified
2. **Self-check prompts** - "Did you run the tests you wrote?" style reminders
3. **Handoff consumption verification** - Ensure receiving agents acknowledge handoff files
4. **Red flags sections** - Add common failure modes to watch for

## Scope

Review all skills in `skills/` directory. Each skill should have:
- Clear verification checkpoints after critical steps
- Red flags for common skipped steps
- Explicit "MUST" language for non-negotiable requirements

title: Improve issue tracking across skills - offer status updates in more places
description:
Currently, issue status updates are offered at specific checkpoints (session start, before completion, after merge). However, there are additional opportunities to offer status updates:

**Current checkpoints (per CLAUDE.md):**
- subagent-driven-development: Branch creation, status update at start
- verification-before-completion: Discovered work, original issue update
- finishing-a-development-branch: Issue close after merge/PR

**Potential additional places:**
- When starting work on a specific task within a plan
- After completing significant milestones during implementation
- When blocked/encountering issues that might affect timeline
- During code review when findings affect scope
- When research reveals the issue needs to be split or rescoped

**Goal:** Make issue tracking more seamless by presenting status update offers at natural workflow points, without being intrusive.

title: Brainstorming should explore codebase structure instead of making assumptions
description:
The brainstorming skill should proactively explore the project structure when any brainstorming involves structural decisions, rather than making assumptions about how the codebase is organized.

**Current behavior:** Brainstorming may make assumptions about project structure without verifying.

**Desired behavior:** When brainstorming touches on structural topics (where to place files, how to organize code, architectural decisions), the skill should trigger codebase exploration to ground recommendations in actual project patterns.

**Examples of when exploration should happen:**
- Deciding where a new feature should live
- Discussing component/module organization
- Planning file structure for new functionality
- Any architectural brainstorming

This makes brainstorming more grounded and prevents suggestions that conflict with existing patterns.

title: Add feedback skill for iterating on design/research/plan documents
description:
Create a feedback skill to be used with brainstorm designs, research outputs, or coding plan documents. The skill should:

- Take user feedback on the document
- Clarify the feedback through questions
- Research any unclear points
- Present possible changes to the user
- Update the document with approved changes

This enables iterative refinement of design artifacts before moving to the next pipeline stage.
